content: I have been studied on the neural mechanisms learning and emotions using informatics and computational approaches. In the past, I used to study them using animal experiments (electrophysiology). I am the vice-director of the Medical Information Education Promotion Office in FHU and a member of the Information Infrastructure Committee of the Japan Neuroscience Society. For the details of the research projects, please check on Projects. For further details on myself, please visit Reseachmap.

title: April 20th 2020 - 2 papers on the depression study were accepted!
April 1st 2020 - Prof. Nakano started a new laboratory @FHU

content:
We are studying a spiking neural network model of the reinforcement learning inspired by the basal ganglia.
We have constructed a neural network model inspired by the cortex and the striatum. in addition, it has a memory structure like the hippocampus. This model can learn optimal actions under some partially observable situations (Nakano et al., PLoS One, 2015).
title: Computational Neuroscience

content: We developed a new drug administration method that allows arbitrary control of drug in the brain using liposomes. We applied this method to stimulate some particular type of dopamine receptors and measured the effects on the cellular functions. This method is useful for biological research.(Nakano et al. 2014, Nakano et al. 2016)
summary: Arbitrary controlable drug administration method using liposome and laser  `past`  `experiment`
title: Development of a novel drug application method

content: We are applying machine learning to multimodal data of neural activity and blood samples from depressive patients.
summary: Analysis of neural activity and blood data from patients with depression `analysis` `machine learning`
title: Diagnosis of depression using machine learning

content:
We have constructed realistic models of the brain at the levels of molecular, cellular, and network to understand the neural mechanisms of the learning and decision-making.
At the molecular level, we constructed a signaling cascade model of the medium spiny neurons in the striatum. We predicted the positive feedback loop amplifies the dopamine signaling (Nakano et al., PLoS Computational Biology, 2010). We also investigated the interaction between adenosine and dopamine based on experimental research (Zhang et al., Neurochemistry International, 2018).
  At the cellular level, we constructed a multicompartment electrophysiological model of the striatal cell including ion channels and receptors with realistic morphology taken from an experiment (Nakano et al., Frontiers in Computational Neuroscience, 2013).
title: Neural modeling

content: We used to conduct animal experiments with electrophysiological techniques like optogenetics and patch clamp recordings from acute brain slices and in vivo animals for validation of model prediction and elucidation of the neural mechanism of learning (Nagai et al. 2016, Nakano et al. 2016).
title: Neurobiology experiment

content:
We are analyzing behavioral/physiological data and medical data from collaborating laboratories.
In our previous works: We analyzed brain activity using dynamic causal modeling during reinforcement tasks avoiding stress in humans. We estimated the connectivity between the hippocampus and habenula (Yoshino et al., submitted). We investigated the interaction between the medial spiny neurons and cholinergic interneurons in the striatum by analyzing in vivo electrophysiological data (Zucca et al., eLife, 2018). We analyzed the behavior of mice related to reinforcement learning using deep learning (Matsubara et al., BioRxiv 2019).
title: Neuroinfomatics
